body: An overnight fire tore through a busy commercial strip in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn yesterday, damaging at least five stores, fire officials said. The businesses, on Fifth Avenue between Seventh and Eighth Streets, were ''heavily damaged if not destroyed,'' Frank Gribbon, a Fire Department spokesman, said. The fire was reported at 3:12
title: Fire Damages 5 Small Businesses in Park Slope

body: During the holiday season, some generous families give to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund instead of giving gifts to one another. ''Enclosed is my annual contribution to the fund in lieu of presents for family,'' wrote Evelyn Landry, 43, of Park Slope, Brooklyn, enclosing a $400 check. She has sent donations for the last five years,
title: Families Give Gifts of Caring to the Community Rather Than to Each Other

body: NEW YORK Children Against Child Labor After reading an article in a children's magazine about Pakistani children toiling 12 hours a day making soccer balls, fourth graders at the Berkeley Carroll School in Brooklyn's Park Slope section began a yearlong project on child labor, joining thousands of others across the nation who have distributed fliers
title: METRO DIGEST

body: Asked just a year ago whether they would have supported legislation to severely curtail the power of community school boards, many parents and teachers in District 15 in Brooklyn would have answered loudly in the negative. The district, which straddles working-class neighborhoods in South Brooklyn and more affluent brownstone blocks in Park Slope,
title: In South Brooklyn, Guarded Desire for Change

body: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will be able to use his new power to hire school superintendents almost immediately in 27 of the city's 32 school districts. The timing of the legislation enacted yesterday coincides with the final months of three-year contracts between all the local school boards and their district superintendents. Five local school
title: Timing Allows Crew To Respond Quickly

body: THE Brooklyn Youth Chorus -- 150 Brooklynites who range in age from 6 to 16 -- has a busy weekend ahead. The singers will perform their fifth annual Winter Concert on Friday night at the Old First Reformed Church in Park Slope and appear Saturday afternoon with the Brooklyn Heights Orchestra at the St. Ann's Holiday Family Concert. The Friday night
title: A Busy Weekend for Brooklyn Youth Chorus

title: Police Say Captured Drug Gang Was a Family-Run Operation

body: The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that he would seek the death penalty in a second case, this one against a 22-year-old man accused of killing another man execution style while stealing a jeweled gold pendant and necklace from him. District Attorney Charles J. Hynes, who has said he opposes the death penalty, is still the only New York
title: Brooklyn Prosecutor Seeks Death Penalty in a 2d Case

body: To the Editor: I attended the District 15 school board meeting at which Superintendent William Casey was fired (''Vote Underlines District Split,'' Nov. 24). To fire a superintendent who by all accounts is accessible, effective in implementing new programs and open to change is foolish. Last year I toured seven District 15 elementary schools: 107,
title: Dismissed Superintendent Triumphed in Many Schools

body: THE history of the Sunset Park community of Brooklyn is a tale of the effect of waves of immigration on community life. In the 1990's, the tale is being retold with new twists. One has been brought about by the arrival of Chinese immigrants from Hong Kong and the mainland in what has come to be known as the Brooklyn Chinatown, which also embraces
title: Immigrants Again Renew Sunset Park

body: To the Editor: No one can envy Debra Jean-Louis or any other manager in charge of a subway station in New York. But if she thinks she has a tough challenge, she should hope she isn't transferred to the Broadway-Lafayette station in Manhattan. In a languid renovation, at who knows what cost, workers installed new lighting with shielded reflectors --
title: Station Manager Inspires Riders to Keep Place Clean

body: To the Editor: Your article ''School's Critics Fix on Tree'' (Nov. 17) seriously misrepresents the Berkeley Carroll School. Our immediate neighbors on President Street have tried to frame their very personal resistance to a new building in environmental terms. Far from being callous, our students and their parents have been in the forefront of the
title: Berkeley Carroll School Is No 900-Pound Gorilla

body: After four months of deliberation, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn has announced that he will not seek the death penalty for a 32-year-old man accused of robbing and killing the owner of a news stand in Park Slope. ''I have concluded, after review and deliberation, that a sentence of life without parole is the appropriate punishment
title: Death Penalty Rejected in Park Slope Murder Case

body: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is directing school officials to begin to evaluate about 15,000 special-education children with the goal of moving as many as possible into regular classrooms starting as early as next fall, he said yesterday. The evaluations, to start in January, would be the first phase of Dr. Crew's proposed overhaul of the city's
title: Chancellor Plans Evaluations For Special-Education Shift

body: The staff of the New York State Public Service Commission has recommended that the commission not approve the proposed merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic unless Nynex agrees to compensate its customers for the loss of a potential new competitor in the New York telephone market. The recommendation, which came in testimony filed with the commission on
title: Utility Panel May Make Nynex Compensate Customers for a Merger

body: During a typical evening rush hour at Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, the traffic police wrestle with cars backed up for six blocks. All around them, the area is teeming with office workers heading home, parents buying groceries and teen-agers cruising. It is evidence that Downtown Brooklyn is outgrowing itself. Chronic traffic congestion has
title: For Downtown Traffic, Growing Pains May Turn Critical

body: In the face of an emotional volley of criticism from parents, teachers and politicians, members of Community School Board 15 voted Wednesday to invite educators to apply for the job of district superintendent. The 5-to-3 vote by the board, with one abstention, effectively ends the nine-year tenure of Superintendent William Casey, who is widely
title: Vote Underlines District Split

body: Plans for Thanksgiving Food purveyors have come up with new items to vary the Thanksgiving menu. Kitchen, at 218 Eighth Avenue (21st Street), in Chelsea, has smoky chile corn-bread croutons for making stuffing, at $3.95 for 5 ounces. Seasonal smoked turkey and cranberry sausages, from the Aidell's Sausage Company, are $4.99 for 13 ounces at Fairway
title: Food Notes

body: The death of Rosemarie Brodie, a bicyclist, on York Avenue leaves me disgusted by the city's response (''The Perils of City Cycling,'' Nov. 3). A car door is opened by a driver into the traffic lane in clear violation of city and state laws, but no charges have been pressed against the driver who opened that door. Officer John Giammarino, a police
title: City Streets Offer No Place for Cyclists

body: BELIEVING that the market for affordably priced cooperatives in New York City boroughs outside of Manhattan is beginning to improve, some developers who have taken over troubled buildings are selling apartments again. Indicative of this willingness to return to the market are the activities of three separate development groups that have worked out
title: Lower-priced co-ops sell again in once-troubled buildings in boroughs outside Manhattan.

body: ASHER JASON had a stack of medical documents to prove that his hospital had overcharged him. His health plan and the hospital had agreed that his colonoscopy 18 months ago should have cost $339. So he wondered why he kept receiving a bill for $1,476. For almost a year, Mr. Jason, a New York literary agent, tried to correct the overcharge. But he
title: Hiring a Consultant to Do Battle When a Medical Bill Seems Unfair

body: WITH winter on its way, my husband and I were making preparations for our annual stay in Florida. Checking the freezer, I discovered that it still contained three pounds of probably the finest Bolognese meat sauce I had ever created. Reluctant to discard it, I decided that my husband, traveling down a week ahead of me, should take the sauce with
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: All 351 passengers and crew appeared to have been killed on Tuesday night when a Saudi Arabian jumbo jet collided shortly after takeoff with a Kazak Airlines plane approaching the New Delhi airport, Indian aviation officials said. The death toll made it the third-deadliest air crash and the worst mid-air collision in aviation history. Rescue teams
title: Two Airliners Collide in Midair, Killing All 351 Aboard in India

body: For years, residents of western Brooklyn have dreaded the upcoming reconstruction of the Gowanus Expressway, a project that would swamp neighborhoods with traffic for at least five years. But an alternative may be emerging: replacing the crumbling elevated expressway with an underground highway. Ultimately, the most important question is whether
title: As Unpopular Gowanus Overhaul Looms, a Tunnel Plan Gains Notice

body: For Robert Dieterich, life as a Nynex customer finally became intolerable last spring, when he started getting calls for Randi Baker, his next-door neighbor in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. After some detective work, Mr. Dieterich discovered that Ms. Baker had asked the phone company to fix her line because it was scratchy. A Nynex repair man
title: New Rivals and Pending Merger Force a Company to Focus on Service

body: Diane Margo Morales, special assistant for families and children to the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, died on Nov. 1 at New York Hospital. She was 52 and lived in Park Slope, Brooklyn. She suffered a long illness, her office reported. Ms. Morales advised Ms. Messinger on social affairs like domestic violence, homelessness and
title: Diane Morales, 52, Community Adviser

body: The word had been out in Park Slope for some time: Barnes & Noble is coming. But no one was quite sure when, or quite sure where. Last week, the ''when'' part of the question was answered: the bookstore chain plans to open its first Brooklyn superstore next year. ''Where'' was only partly answered -- the store will be in Park Slope, but a company
title: It's Official: Barnes & Noble Plans a Brooklyn Superstore

body: Eugenio Duval is poised to rise with, or be crushed by, the good times descending on his lower Park Slope street corner. The problem for the 39-year-old bodega owner is deciding what to stock his shelves with. In a 30-minute period last week, Mr. Duval's store near the corner of Seventh and Prospect Avenues sold a lottery ticket to a middle-class
title: Park Slope Boom Spreads South

body: LAST month, this northern Westchester village stood in for for a small town in Indiana during the filming of a movie starring Kevin Kline, Debbie Reynolds and Joan Cusack. title: A Touch of Rural, and a Lively Downtown

body: For Jill Gartenberg, running the New York City Marathon is like throwing a party. She even mailed invitations. Gartenberg, a 29-year-old speech therapist from Manhattan, sent out 50 postcards (designed on her personal computer and affixed with a marathon stamp) to family and friends, inviting them to cheer her on. Those who could attend were
title: An Organized Runner Maps Out Her Support

body: FROM their rueful scheduling of a child's first play date to their serving of yet another takeout dinner in its aluminum tray, one thing seems to unite New York parents: guilt. ''The city's too dangerous,'' parents worry. ''There's no place for children to play. They can't go outside by themselves. I don't spend enough time with my child.'' This
title: Memo to Guilt-Ridden Parents

body: A dilapidated three-story brick building originally built as a synagogue at 401 Ninth Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn in 1913 may soon become a synagogue again. Although it became an American Legion Post in 1965, its roots as a synagogue remain evident. It still has six stained-glass windows, an ark, a balcony with oak railings and an
title: For an Ex-Synagogue, A Return to Its Roots

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

title: Growth in Downtown Brooklyn Is Still Looking Up, Planners Say

title: The Boom in Park Slope

body: A Federal judge who has been asked to order new primary elections because of ballot problems that kept many voters away from the polls in Brooklyn said that in at least one race, he may instead reopen the polls so that people who did not vote can do so. Many voters could not cast ballots on Sept. 10 because many of the voting machines were not
title: U.S. Judge May Reopen Primary Polls

body: HUNDREDS of shoes -- from scruffy sneakers to spit-shined wingtips -- were piled high on Barbara Hohlt's dining room table on Sunday. Nearby, a dozen people busily rooted through bags and boxes of even more shoes, making her Brooklyn Heights home look like the epicenter of a specialty tag sale. Some shoes' laces were tied to small notes. A note
title: Victims' Shoes Are a Protest Of Gun Deaths

body: To the Editor: Your article ''Is This Man Dangerous?'' was an accurate depiction of the illegal harassment endured by New York City's street artists. I've been arrested 13 times for selling my own paintings on the street, yet I've never had a trial or been found guilty of any crime. To add insult to injury, the city sells the art and art supplies
title: Street Artists Endure Harassment That's Illegal

body: Sure, sure. We know. There's just not enough time in the day, the month, the whole year, for that matter. You would love to exercise, plow through books, play an instrument, learn a foreign language. You'd even floss your teeth if you had more time. But hey, there is only one of you. You have a demanding job, a busy schedule and you've got to sleep
title: Not Enough Time in a Day? Meet the Master Jugglers

body: Voters who turned up for a bitterly contested primary in Brooklyn yesterday were turned away from scores of polling places, because election workers had failed to deliver the voting machines in time. The problem persisted into the afternoon in many neighborhoods, raising the prospect that the election would have to be held again. Officials said
title: Primary Voting in Brooklyn Disrupted by Lack of Machines

title: Driver's Ed, Where Driving Is a Blood Sport

body: There's a patch of wild pink petunias that come up every summer in the cracks of the cement in front of an apartment building on the corner of Sixth Avenue and Sixth Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The sun beats down, but these petunias seem to thrive in their concrete desert, and I always look for them if I'm passing by. Were they part of some
title: Softening Gritty Urban Gray With a Little Green

author: Marina Isola writes about art and culture from Dallas and New York.
body: One of the reasons i got involved with Egyptomania as a collector was as an attempt to understand some of the strange things the public asks me in relation to my serious work,'' says Richard Fazzini, chairman of the Egyptian, classical and ancient Middle Eastern art department at the Brooklyn Museum, which houses one of the finest Egyptian
title: Curators, Too, Can Be Collectors,Within Limits

body: A police officer has been suspended because of allegations that he harassed and stalked his former girlfriend, a civilian employee of the force, police officials said yesterday. Officer Leonard Milazzo, who has been on the force 11 years, was taken off active duty Thursday night. The officer had been transferred to the 78th precinct in Park Slope
title: Police Officer Suspended

body: Labor Day is Monday. This year's Labor Day Parade in Manhattan, however, begins at noon on Sept. 7, proceeding up Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Street. title: Celebrating the Last Gasp of Summer, From the Arts to the Zoo

body: Eda Cawthon reclined on a plastic chaise longue, her eyes obscured by sunglasses and her toes wriggling and pointing at the Atlantic Ocean as she waited for her husband, Craig, to schlep back half a mile from the parking lot. He had dropped her on the beach in Neponsit, Queens, off Beach 147th Street, and would now drive through the neighborhood's
title: Parking Bans Keep Outsiders From Queens Sand and Surf

body: BATTERY PARK CITY Cool Sounds For Summer's End The Bronx Arts Ensemble will give a free all-Handel concert on Tuesday at Hudson River Park in Battery Park City as part of the ''Sounds of the Hudson'' celebration. The program will include -- appropriately enough -- the complete ''Water Music,'' with Kenneth Cooper conducting from the harpsichord.
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Along Fifth Avenue, what was once a strip of empty storefronts, bodegas and Chinese restaurants with bulletproof windows is changing into one of Brooklyn's most eclectic commercial thoroughfares. title: A Funky Renewal Transforms Fifth Avenue

body: Cole Grady was earning $52,000 a year as a technician at a herbicide plant in Muscatine, Iowa, including $15,000 in overtime. title: WAGE VOLATILITY FAR MORE COMMON THAN EVER BEFORE

body: New York City will make its first major service cut in recycling next month when it scales back collections for half the city's households. The reduction -- from weekly to alternate week pickups -- is the first tangible effect of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $26 million cut to the city's recycling budget. The change is to begin Sept. 9. The Mayor
title: New Yorkers Face 2 Weeks of Storing Trash for Recycling

body: To the locked-out and the lock-needy, a buoyant, meditative man named Joel Kostman is their savior. As he navigates his way among the city's venues, lugging his implements in a worn doctor's bag and opening doors that resolutely refuse admittance to their very own inhabitants, he regards himself as one of the people who holds the keys to the city.
title: Doctor Of the Deadbolt;A New York City Locksmith Is the Ultimate Insider

body: The double-digit decline in crime that New York City has enjoyed in the last two years is slowing, police statistics show, with an increase in rapes citywide and a growing number of murders, burglaries and robberies in several neighborhoods. For the city as a whole, reports of serious crime declined 9 percent in the first three months of this year.
title: Drop in Crime Slows to 9% In the Quarter

body: When Michael Tracy learned at the age of 15 that he had a form of cancer known as lymphoma, his world seemed to cave in on all sides. His father had just died of brain cancer, so as he dealt with the grief and fears for his own future, he faced a series of dreaded spinal taps, bone-marrow aspirations and chemotherapy treatments that would fill his
title: Hypnosis Gains Credence As Influence on the Body;It Helps Control Pain, Fear and Habits

body: The wife of Edward J. Leary took the witness stand yesterday in her husband's defense, telling jurors how his behavior became increasingly bizarre and obsessive in the months and weeks leading up to two subway firebombings that he carried out 14 months ago. The wife, Marge Schaller, a pediatric nurse, testified for the defense as Mr. Leary's lawyer
title: Wife Recalls Subway Bomber's Obsessions

body: When he was in junior high school on the Lower East Side, Jose Garcia's days were studded with classes in voice, band, art and music appreciation, a creative cornucopia that eventually led him to a stage career. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;Community Groups Protect the Arts From Extinction in Schools

body: THE thermometer read 15 degrees last Sunday afternoon, but that was not the reason my fingers had turned blue. body: To the Editor: Kudos to Neil Kaplan of Park Slope, Brooklyn ("The Story of My Stabbing," Jan. 21). He may not see himself as a hero, but I do. Intervening to prevent a crime, as he did in an East Side subway passageway, takes courage and a conscience. The Neil Kaplans of this world bring caring and humanity to this city. MARIE SCHLOEDER Brooklyn
title: Stepping In to Stop a Crime Was an Act of Humanity

body: Transit workers found a hand and a foot early yesterday on subway tracks in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the police said. The workers made the grisly discovery at about 3 A.M. on the southbound tracks of the D line at Seventh Avenue and Prospect Park, a police spokesman, Detective Mark Patterson, said. title: Body Parts Found On Subway Tracks

The pharmacies have accused the drug makers of overcharging them in violation of Federal antitrust laws. The lawsuit, one of several parallel actions filed
title: 13 Drug Makers Ready to Settle Pharmacist Suit

body: Most days, Mario Gallegos, a superintendent at an Upper West Side apartment building, leaves the business of tossing bags of refuse onto garbage trucks to New York City sanitation workers. But yesterday, he grabbed a few himself and flung them on the collection truck of Richard L. Bryant and Gene Dalton. Together, the three men loaded about 150
title: Beyond Hills of Snow, Mountains of Garbage

body: A brilliant sun banished a week of daylong dusks, reflecting off expanses of snow, water and glass and luring New Yorkers, blinking and almost giddy, into the light yesterday. Melissa and David Clark were among the many who left slushy gray streets for the still-white fields of Prospect Park in Brooklyn, grinning and squinting into the brightness,
title: Spring? No, But a Thaw Is Sure Nice

body: Two years ago, the McDonald's in Flatbush might as well have hoisted a white flag alongside the flags of Barbados, Grenada, Panama and Puerto Rico that wave from its roof. title: City Is Safer, Rising Number Of People Say;Attitudes Catching Up To 2-Year Fall in Crime

body: When a failed co-op building in Park Slope was scooped up in 1994 by a nonprofit agency to house the mentally ill, it was the target of vociferous protest by neighborhood residents and local politicians. But then a compromise was reached: half the apartments were to be occupied by mentally ill men and women, and the other half was to be turned over
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;A Pledge of Homes, Half Kept

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE MOOD;Siberia on the Hudson: Efficiency, Charm, Everything but the Wolves

body: For Conrad Noble, living with AIDS means keeping a well-stocked medicine chest and knowing when it is time for each of the 31 pills he takes every day. "At first you're very resistant to the medication," he said. "But once you're in pain you take the pill and get used to it." Most of his prescriptions, which would cost more than $2,500 a month,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Now, Living With AIDS Means Paying for More Drugs

body: IN the heat of July two years ago I walked into a pet shop in Manhattan. Like everyone else in the store, I had no intention of buying a dog. I just wanted to look. title: SOAPBOX;Why Do Dogs Love Snow?
